instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the batteryâ€™s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS IS PPBUS_G3H voltage after it has passed through a current sense resistor that supplies the TPS51980 and its associated buck converter with voltage to create the PP5V_S4 power rail..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message:
Hi everyone, I'm stumped here. 

Liquid damage around <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> and battery connector. Replaced corroded capacitors around <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>, got the board to power on then will not enter S4. Then noticed area between <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> and battery connector very hot. <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>, no change.

Rails are
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.55V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.55v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.55
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 0!
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.04V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0      
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.45v                                                                                                               
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message: Not what you want to hear but corrosion around <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> will usually kill the CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message: I was hoping since I had it working initially after repairing the damage that the CPU might be ok. Is the only way to check for bad CPU removing <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and see if it turns on or do I just assume the CPU is shot?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message: You didn't mention it worked. The short on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> must be inside the board too. Is there a short on CPU Vcore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message: I should have worded this better "got the board to power on then will not enter S4". Anyhow CPU VCORE (<SIGNAL>PPV_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>) resistance to ground is 29.3 ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage no S4
threads.message: I wouldn't put too much effort into this thing as the CPU may very well be dead. Corrosion around any Vcore regulators are usually deadly. If this is really the only corrosion on the board expect the CPU to be gone.
